Source Code Documentation¶

Kern Rowduction Package¶

All the usable methods/functions which constitute the Kern_Rowduction package.

kern_rowduction.rowduction.apply_kern_rowduction(df, epsilon, nb_rows_memory=100000)[source]¶
Apply the “Rowduction” process on a DF and returns the reduced DataFrame.

NB : The Rowduction process consists in building a directed graph, extracting its quasi kernel and returning the associated DF.

dfpandas DataFrame

DataFrame to reduce through the “Rowduction” process

epsilonfloat

Threshold of dominance between 2 points: Point1 must be > (1+epsilon)*Point2 for each column

nb_rows_memoryint

Number of rows per batch to process the Rowduction. Smaller it is, less memory it takes but potentially slower it is

rowducted_dfpandas DataFrame

The input ‘df’ DataFrame but rowducted, with only the rows to keep after the Rowduction

kern_rowduction.rowduction.build_uncycled_subgraphs(graph)[source]¶
Build 2 induced subgraphs from the input graph so that both subgraphs don’t include cycles.

That is to say, from a input graph, build 2 sub graphs according to the sense of their edges (departure_node’s value <=> arrival_node’s value).

graphnetworkx DiGraph

Networkx Digraph with all the nodes and edges created basically from the original DataFrame

graph1_primenetworkx DiGraph

A uncycled sub graph with the edges between a lower node’s value to a higher node’s value from the input graph

graph2_primenetworkx DiGraph

A uncycled sub graph with the other edges from the input graph not put into graph1_prime

kern_rowduction.rowduction.epsilon_dominates(point_id_1=<class 'int'>, point_id_2=<class 'int'>, df=<class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>, epsilon=<class 'float'>)[source]¶
From an input DF, check if the input node Point 1 (row 1) epsilon dominates the node

Point 2 (row 2).

point_id_1int

Row index of the point 1 in the pandas DataFrame df

point_id_2int

Row index of the point 2 in the pandas DataFrame df

dfpd.DataFrame

Pandas Dataframe where the point are stored

epsilonfloat

Threshold of dominance between 2 points: Point1 must be > (1+epsilon)*Point2 for each column

flag

A boolean which is True if Point 1 epsilon dominates Point 2 otherwise False

kern_rowduction.rowduction.extract_kernel(graph, all_neighbors_dic)[source]¶
Retrieve the kernel of the input directed graph if there is one.

NB : This function works indefinitely if the graph includes a circuit.

graphnetworkx DiGraph

Networkx Digraph with all the nodes and edges created basically from the original DataFrame

all_neighbors_dicdict

Dictionary of integers (nodes) with all the inner and outer neighbors of the all the nodes

kernellist

A sorted list with all the nodes of the kernel computed.

kern_rowduction.rowduction.extract_quasi_kernel(uncycled_subgraph_1, uncycled_subgraph_2, all_neighbors_dic)[source]¶

Extract the quasi kernel from 2 associated uncycled subgraphs.

uncycled_subgraph_1networkx DiGraph

Networkx Digraph without cycles and with all the nodes and “increasing” edges extracted initially from a bigger input graph.

uncycled_subgraph_2networkx DiGraph

Networkx Digraph without cycles and with all the nodes and “decreasing” edges extracted initially from a bigger input graph.

all_neighbors_dicdict

Dictionary of integers (nodes) with all the inner and outer neighbors of the all the nodes

quasi_kernellist

A sorted list with all the nodes of the quasi kernel computed.

kern_rowduction.rowduction.find_in_neighbors(graph, point_id, all_neighbors_dic)[source]¶
From a graph and a dictionary of all nodes’ neighbors, find all INNER neighbors of

the input node (identified by its point_id).

graphnetworkx DiGraph

Networkx Digraph with all the nodes and edges created basically from the original DataFrame

point_idint

Number ID of the node to analyze in the graph

all_neighbors_dicdict

Dictionary of integers (nodes) with all the inner and outer neighbors of the all the nodes

in_neighborslist

A list with all the INNER neighbords of the node point_id

kern_rowduction.rowduction.find_out_neighbors(graph, point_id, all_neighbors_dic)[source]¶
From a graph and a dictionary of all nodes’ neighbors, find all OUTER neighbors of

the input node (identified by its point_id).

graphnetworkx DiGraph

Networkx Digraph with all the nodes and edges created basically from the original DataFrame

point_idint

Number ID of the node to analyze in the graph

all_neighbors_dicdict

Dictionary of integers (nodes) with all the inner and outer neighbors of the all the nodes

in_neighborslist

A list with all the OUTER neighbords of the node point_id

kern_rowduction.rowduction.rowduct(df=<class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>, rowduction_target='all', epsilon=0.025, nb_rows_memory=10000, step_activated=False, label_col='_krd_default_label_', rowduction_method='separately')[source]¶

Parametrize the “Rowduction” process, apply it on a DF and returns the reduced DataFrame.

dfpandas DataFrame

DataFrame to reduce through the “Rowduction” process

rowduction_targetlist or str

List of label values upon which to apply the Rowduction process. Rows with label values that are not listed will remain intact. If the rowduction_target = “all” (default value), the whole input DataFrame df is reduced.

epsilonfloat

Threshold of dominance between 2 points: Point1 must be > (1+epsilon)*Point2 for each column

nb_rows_memoryint

Number of rows per batch to process the Rowduction. Smaller it is, less memory it takes but potentially slower it is

step_activatedboolean

True if the Rowduction has to be step by step of rows, which avoids memory errors in case of huge input DataFrame df. Otherwise False for a ‘one shot’ rowduction.

label_colstr

Name of the label column which contains the ‘rowduction_target’

rowduction_methodstr

Rowduction method : ‘grouped’ to reduce/rowduct together all Rowduction targets, ‘separately’ to reduce/rowduct each of them separately and then concatenate them together

rowducted_dfpandas DataFrame

The input ‘df’ DataFrame but rowducted, with only the rows to keep after the Rowduction

Unit Tests¶

Units tests on 2 Datasets to detect potential bugs of the Kern_Rowduction package.

tests.test_rowduction.test_rowduction_01_dataset_a(path='/home/hichem/Code/KRD/Kern-Rowduction/tests/data/clean_pima_extract.csv', epsilon=0.05)[source]¶

Test the rowduction on a 0 and 1 values of the label of the Dataset A.

Implemented checks :

-Check if the rowduction reduces the number of rows from the original input df -Check if all “one shot” rowductions and rowduction with a higher batch size (nb_rows_memory) than the total number of rows give the results -Check if rowduct(…) and apply_kern_rowduction(…) give same results when the parameters are similar -Check if it gives the same reduced results with no rowduction_target or equal to “all” -Check if it gives the same reduced results with no label_col (nor rowduction_target) and whatever the rowduction_method

tests.test_rowduction.test_rowduction_01_dataset_b(path='/home/hichem/Code/KRD/Kern-Rowduction/tests/data/clean_adult_extract.csv', epsilon=0.052)[source]¶
Test the rowduction on a 0 and 1 values of the label of the Dataset B. There are less tests

than with Dataset A because the DF is too heavy to “one shot” rowduct it.

Implemented checks :

-Check if the rowduction reduces the number of rows from the original input df -Check if the step by step rowduction works and avoid the memory error due to a too large df

tests.test_rowduction.test_rowduction_0_dataset_a(path='/home/hichem/Code/KRD/Kern-Rowduction/tests/data/clean_pima_extract.csv', epsilon=0.05)[source]¶

Test the rowduction on a 0 value of the label of the Dataset A.

Implemented checks : -Check if the rowduction reduces the number of rows from the original input df -Check if all “one shot” rowductions and rowduction with a higher batch size (nb_rows_memory) than the total number of rows give the results

tests.test_rowduction.test_rowduction_0_dataset_b(path='/home/hichem/Code/KRD/Kern-Rowduction/tests/data/clean_adult_extract.csv', epsilon=0.05)[source]¶

Test the rowduction on a 0 value of the label of the Dataset B. There are less tests than with Dataset A because the DF is too heavy to “one shot” rowduct it.

Implemented checks :

-Check if the rowduction reduces the number of rows from the original input df -Check if the step by step rowduction works and avoid the memory error due to a too large df

tests.test_rowduction.test_rowduction_1_dataset_a(path='/home/hichem/Code/KRD/Kern-Rowduction/tests/data/clean_pima_extract.csv', epsilon=0.05)[source]¶

Test the rowduction on a 1 value of the label of the Dataset A.

Implemented checks : -Check if the rowduction reduces the number of rows from the original input df -Check if all “one shot” rowductions and rowduction with a higher batch size (nb_rows_memory) than the total number of rows give the results

tests.test_rowduction.test_rowduction_1_dataset_b(path='/home/hichem/Code/KRD/Kern-Rowduction/tests/data/clean_adult_extract.csv', epsilon=0.05)[source]¶

Test the rowduction on a 0 value of the label of the Dataset B. There are less tests than with Dataset A because the DF is too heavy to “one shot” rowduct it.

Implemented checks :

-Check if the rowduction reduces the number of rows from the original input df -Check if the step by step rowduction works and avoid the memory error due to a too large df

tests.test_rowduction.test_rowduction_dataset_c(path='/home/hichem/Code/KRD/Kern-Rowduction/tests/data/clean_abalone.csv', epsilon=0.05)[source]¶
Test the rowduction on a 0 and 1 values of the label of the Dataset B. There are less tests

than with Dataset A because the DF is too heavy to “one shot” rowduct it.

Implemented checks :

-Check if the rowduction reduces the number of rows from the original input df -Check if the rowduction for a multiclass dataset reduces the rows with the given rowduction_target but not the others

-Check if the rowduction with all the classes as target (and even more than the ones that actually exist) is equivalent to an “all” rowduction

Main / Examples¶

Main script to give examples of use of the Kern_Rowduction package.

# Import the CSV file as a pandas DataFrame
import os
import pandas as pd
import kern_rowduction.rowduction as krd

PATH = os.path.dirname(os.path.realpath(__file__)) + "/tests/data/"
FILENAME = "clean_pima_train.csv"
EPSILON = 0.05
print("-----", FILENAME)

df = pd.read_csv(PATH + FILENAME)
print(len(df))

# Try to kern rowduct the DataFrame in "one shot"
try:
   df2 = krd.rowduct_df(df, EPSILON)
   print("One shot reduction -> ", len(df2), "remaining rows")
except MemoryError as error:
   print("Memory Error:", error)

# Kern rowduct the DataFrame by step batches of 10000 rows => it avoids the memory error bug
df3 = krd.rowduct(df, EPSILON, [1], nb_rows_memory=10000, step_activated = True, \
   label_col = "Label", rowduction_method = "separately")
print("Step by step reduction V3 -> ", len(df3), " remaining rows")
